inlineContent.text: Being a father of a 3-y.o. daughter, I am trying to minimise screen time for her. But it doesn‚Äôt make sense to completely get rid of gadgets from her life. We live in the world where phones, tablets, etc., are a big part of our daily routine. So it is better to introduce them, but in the proper
safe

way. Since she loves drawing a lot, I thought it makes sense to use that direction for her relationship with gadgets. And as an iOS developer, my first thought was to build a drawing app. I haven‚Äôt used
before, so while learning it, I want to share my experience.
Let‚Äôs look into the basics of drawing with

is a framework that provides an ability to interact with hand drawn content and provides a set of tools for doing that. It accepts input from Apple Pencil or the user‚Äôs finger. This framework provides support for iOS, iPadOS, macOS (plus Mac Catalyst apps) and visionOS.
provides a
that handles user input, displays it in the UI with low latency. In order to start using a canvas view you need a few lines of code:

code: func updateUIView(_ uiView: PKCanvasView, context: Context) {}

inlineContent.text: This framework is quite old and hasn‚Äôt been updated much since iOS 18. As a result, there is no SwiftUI support. It comes from UIKit, and if you want to use it in SwiftUI, you will have to wrap it in
and bridge it into SwiftUI.
Canvas produces a
object that can be saved, and shared. The Drawing object is a proprietary format that is supported by the
framework. You can use it only within the framework. In addition, the content of the drawing can be exported as an image and can be shared as a raster elsewhere.
In order to interact with a canvas, the framework provides a set of tools you can use. There are only three tools available:
. These tools conform to the
protocol. However, it is not possible to make your own tool by adopting to it. Instead, you should create instances of existing tools provided by the framework and only change their configuration.
Alongside the tools,
also provides a way to select and configure them. For that purpose, there is a
that allows the user to pick the tool and change its appearance.
Here is an example of setting up a tool picker with a preconfigured set of tools:

code: func updateUIView(_ uiView: PKCanvasView, context: Context) {}

inlineContent.text: Let‚Äôs have a deeper look at each tool individually.
allows us to delete the object. Deletion can be configured to delete an entire object using
type or
to remove only those portions of the drawing it touches. Alongside the type, you can also specify a width of the portion you want to remove.
allows you to draw lines with a specified pen style, color, and width. Using user‚Äôs touch input, the inking tool draws a
. There are a bunch of ink types available in
that allow users to draw different content with various configurations. Here is a list of all available ink types:
- creates the appearance of a felt-tip marker;
- creates the appearance of a pen-based drawing;
- creates the appearance of a narrow line from a pencil;
- creates the appearance of a monoline pen;
- creates the appearance of a calligraphy pen;
- creates the appearance of a watercolor brush;
- creates the appearance of a crayon.
Here is a code snippet that allows you to create a tool picker with a set of inking tools for each available ink type:
The last available tool is the

. It provides the ability to select stroked lines and shapes on the canvas, which can be moved, copied, cut, or even removed later. The Lasso tool doesn‚Äôt have any configurations like size or color.
You can add the lasso tool to the tool picker by just providing a
instance.
Whenever a user interacts with
, the
object is being updated.
is an object that represents a content drawn on the canvas. Treat it as SVG but with simpler and platform-related details.
allows you to generate a data representation of it, so you can freely save it in a database or filesystem, and share it. From this data representation, you could create a
and display/modify it with a PKCanvasView.
Whenever you share your drawings between different iOS versions, you might need to support a content version of it in order to be able to display or draw on it. There is a specific type,
, that is used in
on the drawing,
in the
, and a similar
on the
. Make sure you set the

for both the canvas view and the tool picker. However, this is only the case if you want to support iOS lower than 17.0. If you are targeting iOS 17 and above, you shouldn‚Äôt care about content version compatibility checks unless Apple introduces a new version of the content version with a new set of inks.
If you still need to support iOS releases earlier than 17, please refer to the
guide.
In addition to the data format for persistence,

also provides an ability to generate an image of the drawing. You can specify a rect (the portion of the drawing that you want to capture) and a scale (the scale factor at which to create the image) when generating an image.
Specifying scale factors greater than 1.0 creates an image with more detail. For example, you might specify a scale factor of 2.0 or 3.0 when displaying the image on a Retina display.

content.text: How to interact with a drawing

inlineContent.text: is just a container for an array of
. Each
consists of an
, and optional
is a B-spline path that describes this stroke. It contains a
and holds an array of control points internally.
Each
contains a set of information about when, where, and how it was drawn. It stores the
of the point and its
(time offset since the start of the stroke path in seconds). There is also information about the touch, like
, and
. And of course, the drawing data: the
of the point, its
, and

(TBH, I don‚Äôt know what this field is about; there isn‚Äôt much information in the documentation about it). ‚Ä¶we can construct drawings from the code, inspect them, and even modify them if needed. So there is room for different features we can build upon that foundation.
has a small set of APIs to modify drawings. You can apply a specified
to the contents of the drawing. Or you can make a
copy of it if you need to generate a new drawing without updating the existing one. Additionally, to transformation, there is a method to
one drawing to another. Similarly to transformation, you can generate a new drawing by
one to another without modifying the source.
As with any other UI components in UIKit,
has a
that responds to changes in the drawn content or with the selected tool.
allows you to listen to start- and end-of-event sequences for the currently selected tool and changes to the drawn content.

In this article, we‚Äôve taken our first steps into the world of PencilKit. We‚Äôve covered the fundamental building blocks, from setting up a canvas to understanding the tools and the data structures that hold our drawings. It‚Äôs been a fun initial dive, and the framework seems powerful enough for creating the drawing app. In the next article in this series, we‚Äôll take what we‚Äôve learned and start building the actual application.
Stay tuned!

abstract.text: This article is a step into the series of articles about building a drawing app with
. In it, I will try to explain the basics and give some general understanding about the framework.

abstract.text: This article explores Kotlin Flow with Swift Combine in Kotlin Multiplatform projects. It details converting between
, highlighting the challenges of type erasure and generics in Swift/Objective-C interoperability, and demonstrates potential runtime issues.

doc://Me/documentation/Me/002_Kotlin-Flo.title: I. Kotlin Flow to Swift Combine: A KMP Bridge.

doc://Me/documentation/Me/003_Kotlin-Flo.title: II. Kotlin Flow to Swift Combine: A KMP Bridge.

abstract.text: This article resolves KMP type-safety issues when bridging Kotlin Flows to Swift Combine. It uses
, a generic wrapper, to ensure type safety in both directions, enabling consistent compile-time error detection across Android and iOS.
This article delves into the new SwiftUI container APIs from WWDC24, showcasing how to build custom, flexible, and performant Layouts using advanced
. It covers practical implementations for section support, item limits, and expandable sections in iOS 18+ applications.
